translated: Thousand-character text in Sanskrit with preface
Compiled by TripiαΉ­aka Master Yijing
The preface is for the sake of those who wish to go to the Western Regions. It serves as a model for learning the language. The Sanskrit sounds are noted below each character.
The Chinese characters are listed.
For those without characters,
the sounds are corrected.
These are all essential characters for the journey.
If one only learns this, then the rest of the language will be understood.
It is different from the old thousand-character text.
If one also studies the Siddham chapter and reads Sanskrit texts,
in one or two years one will be able to translate.
Thousand-character text in Sanskrit: Heaven, Earth, Sun, Moon, Yin,
Yang, Circle, Square, Day, Night, Light,
Darkness, Thunder, Lightning, Wind, Rain, Stars, Flowing,

inferiorπ”½firmπ”½solidπ”½sΕ«traπ”½vinayaπ”½ordinaryπ”½nobleπ”½isπ”½is notπ”½vowπ”½comingπ”½goingπ”½newsπ”½joyfulπ”½resentmentπ”½fullπ”½Postscript to the Sanskrit Thousand-Character Text Postscript to the Sanskrit Thousand-Character Text, written for those who wish to go to the Western Heavenπ”½There are three types of samples of Sanskrit and Chinese language.
The first is Yijing's compilation of the Thousand-Character Sanskrit Text.π”½It is also called the Sanskrit-Tang Thousand-Character Text.
It is also called the Tang-Character Thousand-Garland Sacred Language.
The second is the Sanskrit-Tang News.
The ancient manuscripts and the printed edition by Jiming do not have this name.
It first appears in the printed edition by KeikΕ.
The third is the Tang-Sanskrit Text compiled by Quanzhen.
It is also called the Language and Characters of the Two Countries of Tang and Sanskrit.
However, the contents of the three texts seem to be very similar.

The main text of 800 words by Yijing is exactly the same as the main text of Quanzhen. The first two editions note: The above 200 characters are repeated. Perhaps it means 200 four-character sentences. As for the later text,
starting from the cause and effect of karma up to the twenty-two sentences that can be clearly believed,
the two texts are slightly similar.
The rest are all different texts.
As for the Sanskrit-Tang News,
it only collects and classifies 300 words.
Except for a few words such as hu (barbarian), han (Chinese), kong (lute), and hou (zither).
The rest are all included in the Thousand-Character Classic.
But their meanings are often not continuous.
It is appropriate to name it the Chapter on Single Words in Sanskrit and Chinese.
Yijing's Thousand-Character Classic.
Four characters form a sentence.
Every time it reaches the twenty-first sentence,
It must include five-character four-line verses,
And then change the rhyme.
Sainei KeikΕ once wrote a translation and commentary.
He refuted JikmyΕ's statement that the arrangement of the characters in the text is chaotic.
He elaborately described the meaning of the ten variations of the rhyme scheme in the original text.
But he still doubted the authorship of Yijing.
He said that it was based on the Tang-Sanskrit text of Quan Zhen,
And that the name Yijing was borrowed.
This is truly a great lack of thought.
According to this, the Thousand-Character Classic was indeed composed by Yijing.
There is nothing to doubt.
The Postscript to the Thousand-Character Classic says:
This was written by Δ€cΔrya DΕmon Sanjin.
Xuanzang's Sanskrit name is Jietuottian. Many of the contents also testify to this.
Like the mountain courtyard covered with canopies.
The first rhyme of the sentence The pure field marks the flower pillar
Only those who have seen the pillar erected by King AΕ›oka can speak of it.
Like the text with layers of seats.
The third rhyme of the sentence The cleverness surpasses the market
The defeated one's seat is layered by the victorious one in the debate arena.
The matter is seen in the Nanhai zhuan (Record of the Southern Sea).
The splendor of the third rhyme Jade steps and stone canals
Is also recorded by him.
Sitting on a small bed.
The ritual of turning back and tying the corner of the robe.
Chewing tooth wood and washing.
The fifth rhyme of the custom of smearing with cow dung
Is also transmitted by him.

VaiΕ›ΔlΔ«.
The seventh rhyme of Kapilavastu
Is where the Buddha's footprints are.
The seventh rhyme of looking back and longing for the separate retribution of kindness
If not Master Yijing, who else?
The Chan River water is deep, the Chan master NΔ«lotpala, the morality cliff, the pure VΔ«kαΉ£ΔαΉ‡Δ« Monastery, the dignified appearance of the hall.
The seventh rhyme of copying and examining the honored sΕ«tras
If not the one who obtained the sΕ«tras from the Western Heaven, who else could have reached it?
Praising and singing
The eighth rhyme of the Indian sound and tongue is also shown by the one who transmitted it from the South Seas.
Relying on it to observe it, how can one doubt that this book was compiled by Yijing?
The Sanskrit and Chinese characters of the complete truth
Are created based on Yijing's Thousand-Character Text.
In the later text, the words and phrases for transmitting the Dharma of esoteric teachings are listed.
The words and phrases of the Yoga teachings should be like this.π”½Therefore, Yijing's Thousand-Character Text exists first.
The Sanskrit and Chinese characters of the complete truth are created next.
As for the Sanskrit and Chinese news
Perhaps it was compiled by Yijing before the single-word section.
It is noted that it should be examined later.

1. The Thousand-Character Text in Sanskrit, transmitted by the Great Master of Compassion and Enlightenment, contains a Sanskrit manuscript in horizontal writing in the Toyo Bunko collection, only the Chinese translation, but no phonetic translation.
It is said to be from the collection of Seisonji Temple.

2. The Thousand-Character Text in Sanskrit, published in the 12th year of the HΕei era by the Shingon monk JikmyΕ. 3. The Thousand-Character Text in Sanskrit with phonetic translation and annotations, published in the 2nd year of the An'ei era by the novice KeikΕ. The postscript of the above two published versions states:

This book was copied in four days starting from the 23rd day of the first month of the 8th year of the EngyΕ era, and completed using the original text from the sea. Recorded by the monk RyΕyΕ« of the Tang Cloister of Miidera. The second and third published versions both contain phonetic translations.
The third is a second publication of the second version, but only the phonetic translation and annotations have been added.
The first manuscript only has the meaning translation, but no phonetic translation.
This is feared to be added by later generations of learners.
The specific indication of the Sanskrit sound,
Although not without confusion,
Is extremely subtle and secret.
It may be the later additions and annotations by Vinaya Master Jingyan.
Now both the new and old editions are published.
I dare not add corrections.
In order to let the reader glimpse the whole leopard.
Carved by the Chief Examiner of the Canon in November of the third year of ShΕwa.
